commentBody: Cute. SW was last. Challenging solve. Satisfying.

Nice!  

Had a few misfills -- GeTit before GOTME; teenS before NANAS; _MEND (could be a or e) before OPINE that I promptly deleted under the assumption that 25D was indeed CARLE; and (due to brain farts including mixing up Tuesday and Thursday) Maundy before SHROVE and Barley before BULGUR, but OWL fixed the last, and both STROLLER and RAGNAROK fixed the other -- but mostly I was on the same wavelength.  Except for really wanting the outside song to be yodel... 

Also 39D is my RL name and 52 in a literal sense is what my body is good at doing (I have a condition, FOP, of which the second word is Ossificans), so I'm secretly considering this a me puzzle. Though I guess telling y'all makes that less secret. Also I'm not a KANGAROO, so, uh.
Great puzzle! Nice cluing. Happy Holidays!
What a work of balance.  TIGHTROPEWALKER crossing EGGANDSPOONRACE.
As an Australian subscriber, I assumed " slowpoke" was a US term and that YTD was also a US feature, even though it is common here. The irony!

In a few days, I will be leaving for Africa. The trip will include South Africa and KENYA. Under the first draft of my itinerary for the trip, we had planned to visit a World Heritage Site near Johannesburg called "The Cradle of Humankind." Imagine my confusion to see that verbiage clued with a 5-letter answer.

I'll have to research if there's a similarly named WHS in Kenya to visit. My plan as of now is to only visit Nairobi with day trips to Mount Kenya and Lake Nakuru before I heard to Kilimanjaro and the Serengeti...

So as weird coincidences go this is one of the weirdest. My boss at Cincinnati Children‚Äôs hospital is Dr. Andy Spooner. (Not such a common name, right?) He loves crosswords, is very good at them, knows I‚Äôve published (I‚Äôve challenged him with all my rejects) and has mentioned to me that he‚Äôs toyed with writing them. So I see this byline and immediately text him ‚Äîcongratulations, that‚Äôs amazing, why didn‚Äôt you tell me?
I finish the puzzle and read the constructor notes and who would believe it, it‚Äôs a DIFFERENT Andrew Spooner (my boss is definitely not Australian). How crazy is this!!!

In any case as I‚Äôm doing the puzzle, I‚Äôm thinking, well I definitely won‚Äôt say anything bad about it‚Äîluckily, boss or not, I don‚Äôt have to. This is an exceptional puzzle and even more exceptional debut. Love the long crossers and the clues (SPOONRACE is certainly perfect for this constructor). Lots of clever clues, loved the STROLLER clue (and I had TEENS before NANAS for the other babysitting clue) and CELLMATE. I‚Äôm sure I won‚Äôt be the only one to have BRA for ‚ÄúBroad band‚Äù although I was a bit surprised the NYT would allow a somewhat pejorative term for women. Also loved the GEODE and ‚Äúmarked with an X‚Äù clues. Overall a nice difficulty level for me and appropriate for a Friday.
So congrats Mr. Spooner, whoever you are, for an enchanting debut. I‚Äôm headed to bed as soon as I pick up my jaw off the floor.

I liked the intentional KEALOA at 21D.

The ‚ÄòE‚Äô in DIE/PESETA was the last square to fall. The euro has been around so long now, I thought Spain‚Äôs currency was the PESaTA; it took me a second to pick up on the ‚Äúdie is cast‚Äù misdirect.

Fairly breezy but fun puzzle overall.
Coincidence that Mr. SPOONer had eggandSPOONrace down the middle?

It would appear the Mesopotamia is considered the Cradle of Humankind Civilization, not Kenya (nor Nubia as I guessed).  The clue for Kenya is Cradle of Mankind, not sure if that is the same thing as the Cradle of Humankind, but if there is a distinction, it is a messy enough one that another clue should have been used (IMO of course).
Also still singular if you instead add an A at the beginning.
At last! A puzzle in which *every single entry* is a Spoonerism!

I was so, so sure 49D was ‚Äúrod‚Äù for casting in fishing.  

That has been a lesson of the past few weeks for me.  When a block of the puzzle just won‚Äôt fill in nicely, delete most of it and try again.  Somehow opens the door in my mind to a new cross and ‚Äúaha‚Äù moments.

One of those rare times a puzzle is both not difficult to finish and extremely interesting to work.  I had only one ask-up (Hub knows myriad odd bits), and the rest of the fills seemed to be talking to each other and guided me through to the gold.

Thank you for this holiday gift, Andrew, and congratulations on your debut.  A VERY nice puzzle!  (Have you ever participated in one of those races? Perhaps with one of the Eggers?)
Loved this puzzle.
What a great debut! Thanks, Andrew! Have a fantastic Friday, y‚Äôall. And a great weekend!

Lots to love about this evocative puzzle.  POKE -- a word with a lot of meanings, one of which is a small leather bag or pouch as used by gold miners for gold dust & nuggets, I.e. a MONEY BAG. 

Another is the balancing acts of the  tightrope walker crossing the egg and spoon race. I tried and failed to find footage of some daredevil on a tightrope doing the egg and spoon thing, surmising there would be hundreds of videos. Nada. Wouldn't you watch such a film? Especially if it was a P0RN0 starring a giantess named Miriam wearing only an obi? Will she lose it midway, or will there be a rift in the rope, and was it tied in properly? I promise you there will not be a dry eye in the house; they, and possibly other parts, will all be quite moist: you're gonna die! An EMT is waiting!

And now the camera turns away from the giant stroller on the rope and focuses on the weedy pile far below her, now ablaze, like a funeral pyre for a Norse god at Ragnarok, adding an extra element of tension. But when a lone kangaroo in the crowd calls out "MOA, MOA!" (probably drunk on Mai-Tai's), you opine that this project has gone too far and should be put on hold. Whatever my ambition as an auteur, including such imagery in a serious film is simply low art. If you're going to have CGI creatures, make 'em more like that owl Albus Dumbledore's henchman Bulgur gave to Harry Potter, a kind of replacement for his mother, Lily. Back to the tabletop for some revisions...

Great debut!
As an Australian with family in the RAAF, I had trouble trying to figure out how to fit wedge-tail eagle in and definitely got tunnel vision on that before eventually realising it wanted Kangaroo from the Roundel on the planes
Sadly there is no plural debate to be had for insignia üòÄ

wouldve been a very tricky wednesday or a fine gimmickless thursday.  (are there any gimmickless thursdays?)
but it was certainly charming.
i suppose if a 39A'er were truly to toe the line as is traditionally and not cruciverbally meant, he or she would plummet to their death.

It's 1:22 am. I just finished the Friday puzzle (with a little help from Google and Wordplay). The only trouble with puzzles is that I seem to wake up around 11:30 pm or so in time to continue my Wordle streak (almost 150 now) and to do the Mini and the Crossword--no matter what time I fall asleep. Or I don't go to sleep until after midnight to do it. It seems to be automatic. 

Like when I used to wake up five minutes before the alarm went off to go to work!!!

17A  USHERING might have been a better job--since you could work matinees or evenings: no early mornings!!

Interestingly, Deb,  I didn't even think of your interpretation of 49d. I was thinking that if I wanted to cast some metal pieces, I would need a die to pour the molten metal in.

My grandfather was a tool-and-die man in Detroit back in the 1930s and 40s.
39 across‚Ä¶ New Zealand is not ‚Äúdown under‚Äù. That is what Australia is referred to as. So this clue was very confusing.
Maybe it's the cookie coma, but I found this one Saturday-level challenging. Fair but very tough.
Beautiful job. Nice and clean, fun cluing, no junk. My only regret is that it was over too soon. Do come back and see us again!

Having both a cold and a Christmas holiday threw me off, so I happily attacked this puzzle thinking today was a Monday. Partway through I thought, wow, this is a pretty tough Monday. There'll be a few comments on this one!!!
   Oops.

I frequently find myself frustrated  reading your explanations, because often the described ‚Äúmisdirection‚Äù feels self-created rather than inherent in the clue. Here, a ‚Äúcold one‚Äù that‚Äôs unexpected and unappreciated points pretty cleanly to CALL, so the beer example didn‚Äôt add much insight.  Instead, it seems merely to be trying to illustrate the cleverness of the solver.   Space us, please.
Congratulations, Andrew. Looking forward to next time.

So my gold star streak hit 2000 today. Not much by David Connell and Steve L standards, but a milestone for me. It would have been longer except for some heart surgery five and a half years ago, which means the operation must have been a success. A good cup of coffee, a cat in my lap and a fine Friday puzzle to solve, always my favorite. Who could ask for more?

I liked this one, and not just because I solved this with out look-ups in under two-thirds of my average Friday time having had a lot of blank space after my first pass. 

What was good was how there were relatively few proper names and how they do not cross. And the trivia could be worked out - just a few crossers for Kangaroo and I knew the cradle of humankind had to be in the Great Lakes region of Africa. Much easier than the nicknames of sports teams that have no obvious connection to their location.
In and outside of NZ, where the Moa was found, it should be fairly well known that we don‚Äôt call any part of Aotearoa ‚Äúdown under‚Äù.

GIANTESS reminds me of Superman.





Et tu, emu.
i thought a cold bAth would be unappreciated and that A fit awfully well, so the NE took some time.  Fun puzzle.

I rarely try Friday puzzles but as I and my wife are on a bike tripe in Chile, with not much else to do at midnight ‚Äî the country has chosen to set its time to be two hours ahead of ET, so as to co-ordinate with Brazilian time for commercial reasons ‚Äî I gave this one a go and was happy to be able to get the gold star. Congrats to Andrew for his debut with this enjoyable puzzle. By the way, the view out of our hotel window is breathtaking, prominently featuring the Osorno volcano: https://surl.lu/rmqhav
Having no idea what the end of the world was in Nordic mythology (much less how it would be spelled), I thought a cold CELL might  be both unexpected and unappreciated.

RANGNAROK is surely spoonerism-adjacent for KANGARRO.

and if I told you it was big white boomer in a snowstorm, would that make me a 
white trope talker?

So many riddle clues, where the answer couldn‚Äôt immediately be slapped down without crosses.  But the clues were such that if there was one cross, or maybe two, the answer suddenly was clear. So, initial hesitation left swaths of white for me, but gimmes and good guesses begat Sudden Splats ‚Äì bam bam bams ‚Äì a royal ‚ÄúWhee!‚Äù.

It's a lovely grid design, no?  No scattershot black squares.  It does create islands in the NW and SE, and that NW island provided another Crosslandia gift on top of the splats ‚Äì the Triumphant Return.  Where you are stuck in an area, just can‚Äôt penetrate it, so you au revoir it only to return later and whoosh it in.

So, good feelings all around.  Sparked by RAGNAROK, a word that looks great to me and is fun to say, as well as by excellent clues, including [Baby sitter?] for STROLLER, and [Life partner, perhaps?] for CELLMATE.

Yours is a very promising new voice, Andrew, and I eagerly await more.  Congratulations, and thank you for a scintillating outing!

A fairly fluid Friday. At one point I did idly wonder if the constructor was Australian, and to my amusement it turned out he is. Good on you, Mr Spooner.
Is this going to be Dumbledore week?
LOWART is high praise for kitsch. : /

Nearly 15min below my Friday average, thanks to some lucky "guesses" being correct straightaway.
BTW, would Deb Amlin already have had access to and completed tomorrow's crossword? The image caption almost suggests specific knowledge that it'll be especially tough, or maybe nothing more than the usual expectation of Saturday being the trickiest day of the week. Made me nervous anyway!
Fun, solid puzzle, thanks Andrew, nice debut!

I started last night had to finish this morning. I had so many wrong answers initially and right ones that I took out and put back in several times. I knew the rhyming drink would be a MAI tAI tAI, so I left off the first letter. Then I thought the answer to 20A might be total, so I had tAI for the longest time. I also had teeNs before NANAS, but knowing MAItAI fixed that in my first pass of the downs. Rod before DIE, which led me to dry out before OSSIFY. GOT it before GOT ME. I put in ABORTS and took it out three times. I tried aloe before LILY. Needless to say, this was more like a Saturday time for me. My last correction was fixing what started as total that morphed to GeTUp and finally to GAMUT üòÖ Thank you for the brain exercise after a nice relaxing holiday, Andrew. I think your next puzzle should include spoonerisms!
IMO the clues were really the (not too fun) challenge here. Beautiful grid otherwise! I resorted to easy mode today and flew through it. I hope everyone had a wonderful Christmas!

I really enjoyed this crossword.
What a great start to a crosswording career.

The puzzle was very enjoyable but tough in some areas.  I think it‚Äôs probably one of my favorites. I wasn‚Äôt aware that the constructor was from Australia until I read the editorial comments, but it makes sense with regard to some of his clues.  I‚Äôm also impressed by his ability to make an ‚ÄúAmerican‚Äú style puzzle and have it accepted so quickly!  Thank you Mr. Spooner for sharing your wit and wisdom with us!!!

A very solid debut puzzle, but much too easy for a Friday. Another "themeless Wednesday" offering. 

Liked "Life partner, perhaps?" for CELLMATE. Was troubled by "Broad band?" for OBI, and am hoping that I misunderstood the clue. Cute is one thing, but this seems almost offensive.

Some lovely *words* in this grid: GAMUT, OSSIFY, EPITOMES.

Clues like "Area on which to eat or play cards" for TABLETOP are just not Friday-worthy. How about "Puzzling place", or any number of more cryptic clues?

Still, a very fine debut. I feel a bit let down by the editorial team today.

Lovely one.
Took me a bit longer than usual.
Just the way I like it.
Favorite: [life partner?] CELLMATE. I was stuck on SOULMATE for the longest time. Also, love how he got almost his own name in the EGGANDSPOONRACE.
Misspelled BULGER, which resulted in TREELOVE. I convinced myself that my ideal mate will be a TREELOVER. Nothing wrong with that.

Whew. Typical tough Friday for me but ended up being an enjoyable workout. Most everything fell together with some crosses but then... there was 8 down. Never, ever heard of that and that had me doubting some of the crossing answers, so I would go back and re-examine those. Finally just gave in and managed to get it finished. 

Interesting puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

I am trying to guess how often Andrew meets someone new, only to hear, "Any relation?"  Maybe great-grandfather?"
Probably about as often as I fail to honor my first thought...only to find that it was the right answer after all!

Fun combo at 27 and 30 Across.
All in all, an admirable puzzle, especially as a debut.
Happy Boxing Day!

One of my more interesting jobs was casting director for "Attack of the 50 Foot Woman", but I was hugely embarrassed for all the 48- and 49-footers who showed up thinking no one would notice they were wearing lifts.

Unfortunately I was then (ironically?)typecast as the go-to guy for certain sorts of films. I noped out big-time when they offered me "Godzilla vs. Mothra".

(Ignore the following unless you‚Äôve watched the streaming show ‚ÄúPluribus‚Äù.)

The things that stick with us ‚Ä¶ seeing CAROL in the grid immediately made me think of:

"Hello Carol! This is a recording. At the tone, you can leave a message to request anything you might need. We'll do our best to provide it. Our feelings for you haven't changed, Carol, but after everything that's happened, we just need a little space."

Congratulations on the debut, Andrew. I thought it was a fine puzzle.  Slow but steady progress for me aided by a few guesses and a lucky break (har) on EGGANDSPOONRACE which helped open up a lot. Breaking into the SE corner was a little tough for me and relied on a couple of lucky guesses. Ended slightly above average time for a Friday, so I felt it was dead on. Nicely done.
Congratulations on a fine and clever debut, Andrew -- I hope we see more from you! I loved every bit of it, especially EGGANDSPOONRACE for the win! ü•öü•ÑüèÖ

That was a perfect Boxing Day puzzle; not too taxing, but full of interesting fill. Love the balance of TIGHTROPE WALKER crossing EGG AND SPOON RACE.

Well done on your debut, you should be very proud.

In the tradition of servants getting the day off on the 26th I refuse to cook on this day, having cooked up a storm to feed the 5000 leading up to Christmas. After mucking out the Alpacas I‚Äôve had a lovely day lolling in front of the fire (it‚Äôs a bitter cold Easterly out there), stuffing my face with cold turkey and chocolate‚Ä¶occasionally in the same bite. The crossword done I‚Äôll turn my attention to Wordle and the Bee, possibly with a nap in between. Heaven.

Weird how minds work. I like to pick a different random word for the Wordle and today TROPE popped in my head for no apparent reason. Only afterward did I realize its connection to this puzzle (TIGH)TROPE. Can‚Äôt be a coincidence, somewhere in my subconscious brain some neuron was turned on about that.
That was difficult. One hour and seven minutes. Required a lot of guessing.
Happy to finish today‚Äôs puzzle! it shoud have extended my streak to 188 but it‚Äôs stuck at 187. Will this eventually resolve or should I contact someone somehow?

Apparently I mis-understood 44D and never noticed GeTME was wrong.  I was focused on the MIRIAM/MOA cross which turns out I guessed correctly, but could not come up with porno since I had PE_NO due to GeTME.  Blue star today unfortunately.

This took me twice my average. 
I have never had so many answers I knew that were right, be wrong. They were in so many corners. 

Soulmate was my starter for the NE. Instead of TRUELOVE. 

Mealtray (then GIANTbra) for GIANTESS. 

I knew emu was probably wrong for MOA. but I‚Äôd like Oreo clues. There are always new ones showing up. 

Plus others I can no longer remember. 

So much ‚Äòerasing‚Äô. 

But proud of myself for golding it. At 1:01:19.

So I guess the ROC can't be extinct if, according to Google, it's a "legendary" bird.  Somehow I thought it was a real bird that went extinct and it was my go-to 3-letter puzzle bird.  (Other than the EMU, of course, which isn't extinct.)  ROC went perfectl;y with COINED for "Made up", but MIRIAM brought me crashing down from my two wrong answers.

So it's the MOA.  Have I ever heard of the MOA?  Darned if I remember.  I'll make a mental note to remember it -- though, of course, a mental note isn't worth the paper it's printed on.

My only other real problem was RAGNAROK, which I don't remember ever seeing before.  But it's correct, I'm pleased to say.

EGG AND SPOON RACE?  I suppose you have to run as fast as you can while carrying an egg in a spoon and not dropping it?  I'll look it up.  The bizarre tests of "athleticism" people invent.  I'm sure that even fifty years ago I would have dropped that egg before going even three steps.

A smooth Friday themeless with just the right amount of crunch.  I didn't find it hard, but neither did I find it boring.  And I applaud it for having almost no junk at all.

On the topic of "de-extinction," I recently read that bioscientists brought back the dire wolf. That's pretty cool, especially for Game of Thrones fans, but is it really a good idea? What's next, sabre-toothed tigers? At least a MOA won't rip your face off.

Fine Friday puzzle, by the way, with a frisson of unknowns, like TACOS de canasta. And Moses had a sister? Also, KENYA's western border is the Great RIFT Valley. (Thank you Dr Leakey.)
Bravo, Andrew! The crosses were brilliant. More please!
On a tightrope throughout the puzzle!!!
You know how sometimes you're just not on the same page as the puzzlemaker? Today I wasn't on the same planet.

Very nice. Faster than Thursday's even.
In fact so good for a Friday [for me] that I've started tracking it to see if I can beat it. Unfortunately, my best times for ThuFriSat are all from 1993 archive puzzles before the difficulty progression began, so I have basically NO HOPE of ever beating those.

P.S. Still wondering WHERE I knew the pre-euro Spanish currency from. Forgotten Hemingway novel?
Struggled a bit in the SE (GeTME?) but did not get boxed in.  Nice debut.  Many thanks.
Nice debut! This was kinda tough‚Ä¶ aha, it‚Äôs Friday!
Lots of fun. Hard but I only had to look up the end of the world. Loved the unexpected twists.

This was very hard for me, taking about twice my personal best time, but without ever getting stalled. I am typically underwhelmed by the mundanity of the lowercase answers. But today's puzzle involved a number of lovely entries: LOW ART, BULGUR, MONEYBAG, OSSIFY, BRASH, EPITOME. And SHROVE as a past tense of "shrive" is perhaps the most interesting of all (even if it's capitalized).

once again, i had that feeling of hopelessness when i first saw the layout of this puzzle

but chipping away at it, i finished, with no lookups, and at a decent time 21:41

just enough crunch for a lazy morning

happy friday, everyone!
A DIE is also a type of mold used for casting metal. I think that makes more sense for 49D. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Die_casting

A belated Merry Christmas, and a Happy Boxing Day, fellow solvers. I am sure feeling like a SLOWPOKE after the last few hectic days. Fortunately this puzzle was lovely, and in my wheelhouse. Have a great day.
I don't mean to be smug, but I scored a TKO on this Boxing Day puzzle. Excellent Friday debut, Andrew!... especially enjoyed 53A. Look forward to more of your challenges.

Here we are, our Christmas revels hardly over--the Feast of Stephen, to be precise (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lGTt4mlRwJE&list=RDlGTt4mlRwJE&start_radio=1)--and Mr. Spooner is rushing us to Quinquagesima! Ah well, so be it--here is a little music for MARDI Gras/SHROVE Tuesday--get those donuts a-fryin'!: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nh1KYgz8U1Q&list=RDNh1KYgz8U1Q&start_radio=1 Speaking of the Feast of St. Stephen, here's a little ditty which premiered Dec. 26, 1199: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r1NWaGE4jmQ&list=RDr1NWaGE4jmQ&start_radio=1 (Talk about retro!)

Today's email containing the easy mode puzzle also includes an  interesting discussion of how the editors decide which puzzles to run when.  I don't know why these things only exist in the easy mode emails,  but I suggest that people consider signing up for the emails even if you're not interested in the easy mode.
I don't do the Spelling Bee puzzle, so I have to ask; did anybody try entering SLEAZO today? I bet it's not on Sam Ezersky's list.

What an incredible debut, Mr. Spooner! Congrats on a solid Friday puzzle. The smattering of personal don't -knows with difficult, but gettable, crosses was the perfect balance. Speaking of...the "balancing act" of the two crossing spanners? Well done! 
Also, I don't know if it was intentional, but I smiled at "short diner order" adjacent to a short "stack", which was my first thought before BLT.

The typing monkeys got a day off. I was able to puzzle out the few remaining squares in the brutal NE. That‚Äôs the sign of a very enjoyable crossword. Even though you don‚Äôt know it you can work it out. 

Happy New Year Y‚Äôall

The editor's original puzzle is available online, and the extent to which the original, clever, relatively difficult clues were butchered to make them as easy and dull as possible is a real drag. There used to be a shred of confidence here in solvers' intelligence, and it's really a shame the extent to which that's no longer true
Absolutely brutal that a PeRNO is a bolt that can be marked with an x, and ‚Äúget me‚Äù just sounds better than GOT ME
Yay, we all survived another holiday season, unless you're doing Kwanza. Hope everyone had a good, and not too stressful, holiday season.
49D is even more diabolical than you think. Dies are (were?) used in some metal casting. When I was a kid in the 1950's we had die cast toys, mostly small cars and planes.

I've solved every puzzle thus far this week in under my average time for the day, some well under average. I'm not guessing or implying from that these puzzles are becoming easier in general, though. It might be a combination of becoming more skilled and being more relaxed for the holidays (the latter only because I avoided all news and social media on Christmas Day). 

Regardless, I never post my actual times, because I'm only competing against myself. Competition in casual gaming should be fun, not stressful. :-)

I had so many wrong answers throwing sections off. The worst in the SE, where I can tell you my guess of GlAmazon starts with the ‚ÄúG‚Äù I knew was correct from the cross and uses the same number of letters as the answer, GIANTESS.
Misspelling words like BULGaR and being unsure of spellings like ALBUS made it all feel tentative. Good puzzle, though. We don‚Äôt use words like OSSIFY often enough.
Seeing 8D reminded me of a peculiar tradition that takes place in SW Kansas each year on SHROVE Tuesday: https://pancakeday.net/history/
Enjoyed it.  Thank you!
For some reason,  CELLMATE for ‚ÄòLife partner, perhaps?‚Äô really shook me! üòÜ

Whoa!

RAGNAROK crossing SHROVE was very tough for me.
This is one of those days where my BLUE STAR = Me Learning something. OSSIFY being the big one, an actual, usable word (not random trivia, which is fun but not exactly OFUSE)

I‚Äôm still a ‚Äúbeginner‚Äù at the NYT. My process is to get as far as I can without any help, then when I‚Äôm truly stuck I check the column for the ‚ÄúTricky Clues‚Äù section to get me unstuck in many of the corners.

Fridays are horrendously difficult for me, so even with these, I end up looking at Mr. Google for certain answers. I‚Äôm proud to say I performed today without it this time, able to get through most of the cluing with no help. I had no idea what a SHROVE, cobbled together with crossings. I don‚Äôt know why EPITOMES was the answer for 34, but it made everything fit!

Maybe one day I‚Äôll solve the puzzles after Wednesdays without looking at the column, but today I feel like I finally evolved and made progress at my crossword puzzle skills.
Whew the SHROVE RAGNAROK cross was a doozy for me. The rest of the puzzle was a satisfying and enjoyable time!

I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle. It was one of those where after I went through the acrosses with almost nothing. I thought the downs would be my saving grace. Alas, no. Not much there either. Picked it up an hour later, and it all came together. A reminder that I can do hard things.
Unfortunately, my 18 day no lookup solving streak came to an end. Too many gaps in knowledge for me today. Tomorrow is a new day
Loved CELLMATE as a life partner, but I hated GIFT clued as facility.
What a lovely, sparkly, and difficult (for me) puzzle! Thank you Andrew, and I hope to be challenged by you again soon!
I must protest the wording of 39A. Moa were never found Down Under. They were endemic to Aotearoa New Zealand, which is down under Down Under.
A total war for me, coming in at what I imagine is a personal worst of over 40 mins. Had to put down and pick up multiple times. Ultimately a great challenge. Nice one!

@Isabeau

I‚Äôm so disappointed your real name isn‚Äôt Isabeau, I‚Äôve told you before how much I love that name from the movie ‚ÄúLadyHawke‚Äù. Although Miriam is also a lovely name!

@SP  üíú

It would be hard for my parents to have named me after the movie character since my existence predates that of Ladyhawke -- okay yes the name existed before that, but shh -- but back in the age of the internet dinosaurs we weren't supposed to use our RL name, so I picked Isabeau in honor of LH and it's sorta just stuck.  Really, Isabeau has been a persistent enough internet pseudonym for me that it's as much my name as Miriam is, in all ways except legal documentation. 

Doesn't work as well in  spoken environments though, because no one knows how to pronounce it right (unless they know Ladyhawke, and that's rare). People generally want to say is-a-byoo, like the first syllable of beautiful... sigh.

Meanwhile I'm about due for another rewatch of Ladyhawke :). It's such a great movie.

@Isabeau mispronunciations can be so frustrating. Have they never read the word/name Beau?

I have never seen the movie, but have added it to my list after reading this thread. So I will soon find out if I have been mentally pronouncing Isabeau correctly

@C

Ladyhawke is a cool movie, well worth a watch.
It seems to be in reference to this site: https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/801 Unfortunately too far, being in the far north of the country, near the border with Ethiopia
@Steven M. Hope you‚Äôre planning to visit Cape Town, one of my favorite places on the planet!

@Steven M.
What a trip!  The only way we can all come along is if you tell us about it in the comments, so be sure to squeeze in some puzzle time along the way.
@Deb Amlen I am

@Steven M.

@Margaret from Brooklyn

Upon reflection, I think I my misinterpretation of the clue was in part due to the question mark, which suggested to me that the clue was to be considered something different from a plain ‚ÄúBroad band‚Äù, which would have been a perfectly good clue for OBI.

Do we really need a question mark to highlight that the clue is a ‚Äúplay‚Äù on the word ‚Äúbroadband‚Äù, which never appears as two words in any case? 

My sense is that more and more clues are appearing with question marks (and that some of these aren‚Äôt needed at all). I wonder if anyone has data to confirm or refute this.

@Howard Sometimes the puzzle completes in your browser but does not sync to the NYT servers. My trick for this is to check the puzzle in a different browser or on a different device. If it's incomplete, complete it again.

@Grant
I vaguely recall, but am not gonna look it up, that the dire wolves that they brought back are not the same as a GOT dire wolf.

@Vaer - These are not real dire wolves. They are genetically modified grey wolves. 

My memory is that they modified a handful of genes -- maybe a dozen? --  related to *appearance* such as type of fur, underfur, coloration, etc, and edited them to match the appearance of dire wolves. 

Modifying a dozen genes to make something resemble an extinct species is not "resurrecting" that species. 

Sadly, it is much sexier for journalists to hop onto the "resurrected" story, so the skepticism of the scientific community around these critters doesn't get the coverage it deserves.

@NYC Traveler
Maundy Thursday is s'posed to be the day for pancakes....

@Mean Old Lady

No, @NYC Traveler is correct.

Maundy Thursday is an observance of the Jewish Passover Seder, aka the Last Supper. It is part of what is known as The Passion Story. 

Shrove Tuesday or Mardi Gras is pancake day which marks the end of Shrovetide and the beginning of Lent.

@Robinette
It has been more than 50 yrs, but the Methodist church I attended in college ( and worked for as MYF cook) had a pancake breakfast annally on that day.  
Mardi  Gras permeatesthis part of the South (NOLA is close by) and pancakes are the last thing on anyone's mind.  
"Communion" commemorates the Last Supper, and is (to say the least) far more frequent.

@Ziggy

Congrats!! Keep at it and you will get better and better and no longer need to look at the column etc. Of course it's always okay to if you do need to. 

To me, it feels really good to be able to complete the puzzle without any help, but each person gets to choose how they want to solve. 

An epitome is the perfect example, or illustration if you will of a thing or a concept. It's a way to actually see a concept.

For example, your response was the very epitome of grace. 

Hope that helps!
